awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Fault-rock trapped-charge and 4He/3He thermochronometry: new  paleothermometers to assess scales and rates of fault slip
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Margaret Odlum has been awarded the NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research as well as a professional development plan at Utah State University (USU) under the mentorship of Professors Alexis K Ault and Tammy Rittenour. The goal of the project is to develop new approaches to fingerprint past earthquakes in fault rocks. Pinpointing evidence of ancient seismicity is important for understanding earthquake processes and mechanics and building a more complete record of fault activity, which collectively inform hazard assessment in seismically active fault systems. Most of the energy during an earthquake is given off as heat, which imparts a thermal and/or chemical signature in fault rocks. Proposed research uses coupled luminescence properties of minerals and He isotope thermometry integrated with textural analysis to access the thermal record of earthquake events across the full range of seismic slip rates, as well as temporal and spatial scales to inform fault slip processes. Complementary age information provided by these methods will provide a more continuous record of deformation over historical to geological timescales which is essential to understand earthquake cycles in a particular fault. This research will be conducted on the Wasatch and Hurricane faults in Utah. These are young, seismically active faults that are adjacent to Utah’s two largest population centers along the Wasatch Front and in the Saint George region, respectively. New approaches developed here will create pathways for researchers to quantify the spectrum of fault slip behavior in other fault systems. Dr. Odlum’s professional development plan is aimed at growing STEM workforce and engaging women, an underrepresented group in Utah in STEM, in earthquake science research and geotechnical skill-building. A seismic hazards module developed in partnership with the Utah Geological Survey will impact students enrolled in the new USU GeoPaths program, and reach a wider undergraduate community by sharing the module with other universities located in the Intermountain Seismic Zone and Wasatch Front region, as well as online through the USU Geosciences webpage and GeoMinutes YouTube channel, thus extending the reach and impact of this work.

The goal of this research is to develop new approaches to identify, quantify, and date frictional heating caused by seismic slip in the rock record across the full range of seismic slip rates (micrometers/sec to tens of meters/sec). Much (~90%) of the energy budget during an earthquake goes into work done overcoming frictional resistance and dissipates as heat. The magnitude of temperature rise across a fault is a function of slip velocity, material properties, and strain localization. Frictional heat, in turn, impacts these factors and the interplay between variables controls fault strength during the seismic cycle. Transient, elevated temperatures impart textural and/or geochemical signatures in fault rocks. This project will combine trapped-charge analysis on quartz and feldspar with hematite and apatite 4He/3He thermochronometry of fault surfaces and underlying host-rock to recover paleotemperatures associated with seismic slip. The seismically active Wasatch and Hurricane faults in Utah will be the first field sites for applying this novel approach. Both seismogenic normal faults have textural evidence of past coseismic frictional-heat, bulk hematite (U-Th)/He dates that reflect thermal resetting or mineralization during earthquake slip within the viable age range for trapped-charge thermochronometry (<0.5 Ma), and pose seismic risk to large population centers in Utah. Coupled paleotemperature and textural information from fault surfaces will inform dynamic weakening mechanisms operative during coseismic slip and improve understanding of rheological changes to fault materials that accompany fault thermal evolution and in-situ earthquake mechanics and fault strength in the upper seismogenic zone. Complementary temporal information on fault slip from trapped-charge and 4He/3He thermochronometry will fill a critical temporal data gap between historical, geodetic, and paleo-seismic (1 - 10,000 years) and low-temperature thermochronometric (100,000 - 1,000,000 years) records of deformation, with direct applications to seismic hazards assessment. The new thermochronometric approach to extract coseismic fault temperatures and temporal constraints on deformation applied here is transferable to other fault systems, giving researchers new tools to access the record of fault slip across seismic slip rates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award was a postdoctoral fellowship that supported an early career female scientist (PI Odlum) through research projects, outreach opportunities, and professional development activities at Utah State University (USU) under the mentorship of Alexis Ault and Tammy Rittenour.

            The purpose of the research project was to develop new approaches to identify, quantify, and date frictional heating caused by earthquakes in the rock record across the full range of seismic slip rates (10-4 to 101 m/s). The research involved studying two seismically active regions in the southwestern United States, the Hurricane Fault in Utah, and the Rio Grande Rift in New Mexico, using novel thermochronometers coupled with field and microstructural observations of brittle fault rocks.

            The main goal of the project was to develop and test luminescence (i.e., optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) and thermally stimulated luminescence (TL)) as new fault rock thermometers and chronometers. Fault rock samples were collected from the Hurricane Fault near La Verkin, UT and quartz OSL and TL was measured as a function of depth away from the fault surface to look for spatial trends. Luminesce trap parameters show variation in trap depth, trap lifetime, and sensitivity as a function of depth from the slip surface that is likely due to mechanical processes, fluids, and/or elevated temperatures that work constructively to transform fault materials during earthquakes. These results highlight the importance of assessing the scale of fault related impacts on host rock and luminescence properties that are important for using OSL and TL as faults rock thermometers and chronometers. The TL signals show compelling evidence for signal loss at the slip surface that we interpret is from a combination of coseismic heating, mechanical, and fluid related processes during deformation. The OSL signals are uniform throughout the fault rock volume but may provide information on the exhumation and faulting in the very shallow crust (<1km) over the to 105 timescales. TL and OSL results are critical for showing the validity of this method and providing benchmarks to understanding and isolating the signature of heating along brittle fault surfaces. The OSL dates could support this technique as a robust tool for recovering temporal information that fills in a critical age range in paleosesimic records, which is important for understanding earthquake recurrence intervals which leads to better seismic hazards assessment.

            The study in the Rio Grande Rift showed that hematite fault mirrors from the Sandia Mountains, NM record Miocene rift related earthquakes. Hematite fault mirror microtextures provide evidence of fault reactivation, intense strain localization, and high temperatures at the fault surface. The hematite textures are related to the mineral composition of the deforming zone, providing a natural example of how fault zone mineralogy controls the strength and stability of faults. Nanoscale analysis of a fault surface reveals new textures that have not been previously documented on hematite fault surfaces and may provide insights into the seismic and post-seismic evolution of thin slip surfaces in damage zones of normal faults. The key findings from this study include: (1) fault zone mineralogy and rheology control the coseismic temperature rise in natural fault rocks, which has implications for thermally mediated dynamic weakening processes, (2) that the fault slip is Miocene or younger and associated with Rio Grande Rifting, and (3) that hematite microstructures and dates can provide important information on processes operating within the shallow continental crust. The results are important because the city of Albuquerque lies near or along some of the studied faults that are capable of producing large earthquakes.

            The project supported a female postdoctoral researcher (PI Odlum) and established a multi-tiered (undergraduate, postdoctoral, early and mid-career faculty) female mentoring network, which was particularly important in Utah which ranks last in the nation for women employed in STEM and for women enrolling in college in STEM fields. PI Odlum co-mentored an undergraduate female student on related earthquake research that culminated in a first author paper (Taylor et al., 2021). PI Odlum developed a field educational module along the Wasatch fault for USU and Weber State’s summer field camp, informing an underserved population about relevant Utah seismic hazards, in collaboration with E. Kleber and A. Hiscock from the Utah Geological Survey. PI Odlum obtained training and experience in new research directions, curriculum development, and student mentoring that gave her skills needed as a tenure-track faculty at an R1 institution.

            Results from this project have been disseminated though two peer reviewed publications (Odlum et al., 2022a, 2022b; one of which is open access), talks at major Earth science conferences, and invited talks at other US institutions. Two additional publications with the full suite of luminescence measurements and results from the Hurricane Fault are in preparation for publication.
